stem: A 45-year-old client is scheduled for a total hysterectomy in 1 hour. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Final pre-operative check and consent signing.
Background: Scheduled for elective hysterectomy for uterine fibroids.
Assessment: Client states, 'I signed the form, but I'm still not sure how they are getting the uterus out or if I'll be able to have children later.'
Recommendation: Assess for informed consent validity.

tabs.title: Pre-Operative Interview & Consent Verification
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemPatient StatementNurse Action Required
Procedure understanding'Not sure of the surgical approach (Vaginal vs Laparoscopic)'Verify Education
Risk/Benefit awareness'I didn't know there was a risk of bladder injury'Critical Gap
Consent SignatureExisting signature on file from clinic visitLegal Verification

tabs.title: Surgical Note
tabs.content: Surgeon's clinic note 1 week ago: 'Discussed risks and benefits. Patient agrees to proceed.' No specific details on patient's verbalized understanding.

actionOptions.text: Notify the surgeon that the client has unanswered questions
Explain the surgical risks and benefits to the client
Withhold the pre-operative sedative until the surgeon speaks to the client
Proceed with the checklist since the signature is on the form

parameterOptions.text: Client's ability to explain the procedure and risks
Documentation of the provider's follow-up discussion
Presence of family members in the waiting area
Pre-operative vital signs and platelet count

rationale.correct: Despite having a signature, the client has expressed a lack of understanding regarding the procedure and its consequences (c1). Informed consent is a PROCESS, not just a paper. The nurse's role is to ensure the process is valid. The nurse MUST notify the surgeon (a1) and withhold any sedatives (a3) that would impair the client's ability to receive new information. Parameters include verifying the client's comprehension (p1) and documenting the surgical re-education (p2).
clinicalPearls: The NURSE witnesses the signature. The SURGEON provides the explanation.
If the client has questions about the 'Why' or 'How' of surgery, the nurse must call the provider back.
A signature obtained after the client has received sedatives (Midazolam) is legally invalid.

questionTrap.trap: The nurse explaining the risks themselves to save time.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Incorrect! Explaining the procedure risks/benefits is outside the nursing scope of practice for surgical consent. Only the person performing the procedure (Surgeon/NP/PA) can provide this.

mnemonic.title: Consent Roles
mnemonic.expansion: Surgeon = Spells it out. Nurse = Notes the signature.
